Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge properly applied the correct legal standard in determining that the wife could remove the children to Greece… The judge followed the principles set forth in Hale v. Hale… which adopted the less strict standard of D’Onofrio v. D’Onofrio… The less strict standard, sometimes called the ‘real advantage’ standard, has been followed with variations in most jurisdictions which have considered the issue… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

DiStefano v. Perez, 476 Mass. 180 (2017).relevant_excerpt: “We balance the competing interests of public access and the right to a fair trial by making the common-law presumption of public access rebuttable for ‘good cause shown.’ … Under Rule 7(b), ‘[i]n determining good cause, the court shall consider all relevant factors, including, but not limited to, (i) the nature of the parties and the controversy, (ii) the type of information and the privacy interests involved, (iii) the extent of community interest, (iv) constitutional rights, and (v) the reason(s) for the request.’”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ ... Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking."

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: "In deciding whether a support provider has the ability to meet his support obligations, the judge must consider all attendant circumstances.
